metadata.title: Neural Networks should learn how to say “I’m not sure” | by Riccardo Di Sipio | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Neural Networks should learn how to say “I’m not sure”
metadata.description: If there is one application of Machine Learning that is known to be particularly useful and often successful, that is classification. Classification is the task of assigning a given entry to a single…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: The use of multiple measurements in taxonomic problems

all_paragraphs: If there is one application of Machine Learning that is known to be particularly useful and often successful, that is classification. Classification is the task of assigning a given entry to a single class (e.g. “cat” or “tiger”?). Usually, each entry to be processed is represented numerically as a vector of numbers, which can encode high-level features (e.g. the length of the tail, the presence of stripes or spots, etc.) or low-level ones (e.g. the value of each pixel in an image). Over the years, a lot of different classifiers have been explored by the community, the most popular ones being artificial neural networks, decision trees, support -vector machines, or other algorithms such as k-means clustering. In this article I will focus on neural networks, but the argument can be adapted to other types of classifiers.

Typically, a neural networks consists of one input layer (that “accepts” the input features), a number of hidden layers (the larger this number, the “deeper” the network), and an output layer. The output layer usually has one single node for binary classification problems (e.g. cat vs tiger), or N nodes in the case of more than just two classes (e.g. cat vs tiger vs lion). Often, students are presented with a simple classification problem called Fisher’s Iris dataset. One has to create a classifier that is able to separate the three species of a flower called (versicolor, setosa and virginica) based on four simple input features (sepal length and width, petal length and width). The dataset was first introduced by the statistician Ronald Fisher in his 1936 paper The use of multiple measurements in taxonomic problems.

This problem is known to be particularly easy to be solved, while still retaining many educational aspects. We’ll try to solve it with a particular neural network that embeds Bayesian inference in order to give not just an answer, but an answer with an associated uncertainty. The code used for this post is publicly available at https://github.com/rdisipio/DeepBayesIris .

Why do we care about uncertainties in the first place is an almost philosophical question. To put it simply, any human being (at least the reasonable ones) would feel the difference between saying “This is an Iris setosa” and “This looks like an Iris setosa, but there’s a 30% chance it is an Iris virginica”. Most of the classifiers can only give a result that looks like the former sentence, mostly because the latter is very hard to compute. The way this is accomplished is by relying on Bayes’ theorem: upon acquiring new information about something, one’s belief (“a posteriori probability”) is “updated” by a mixture of what is observed (“evidence”) and what was known before (“a priori probability”). In particular, if the initial belief is very strong, no evidence can change one’s belief (think for example of the confirmation bias). In practice, the theorem express with a mathematical formula in terms of probabilities associated to the hypothesis (H) and data (D):

In our case, the hypothesis H will be a set of parameters that define the behaviour of our classifier, and the priors will be our initial guess of the actual values of these parameters. By solving Bayes’ theorem, we’ll come up with another set of parameters H* (“best fit”) that improve the overall ability of the classifier to assign each flower in the dataset to the correct category. If you are already familiar with neural networks, this set of parameters corresponds to the weights and biases of the network, and the likelihood to the loss function.

For this particular application, I set up a fully-connected feed-forward multi-layer perceptron (a mouthful, but it’s in fact the simplest type of neural network!) with four input nodes, one hidden layer with five nodes and tanh activation, and an output layer with three nodes (one for each category) and softmax activation . The softmax function makes sure that the result can be interpreted as a probability, , i.e. each node has a value between 0 and 1, and the sum of all nodes is 1. The loss function is cross-entropy, which appropriately measures the performance of a classification model whose output is a probability value.

Before we delve into the details of the implementation, let’s clarify how we’re going to use this kind of network. To start with, we’ll find the optimal set of weights and biases H* that optimizes the loss function — in this context we’ll be looking for the maximum of the function, not the minimum as happens in traditional machine learning software packages. The result of this “Bayesian training” will be a set of parameters and uncertainties. Additionally, we want to estimate the correlations between parameters, which we’ll need for the inference as explained below. In the inference step, we’ll predict the class of a given entry by the means of a neural network with the same architecture, but executed multiple times, each time with a slightly different set of parameters. The average of all these runs will give us a central value and the associated uncertainty.

The actual implementation is based on two C++ software libraries that are popular in the high-energy physics community: ROOT (developed by CERN) and the Bayesian Analysis Toolkit (BAT). Behind the scenes, BAT explores the multi-dimensional probability distribution of H with a statistical method called Metropolis-Hastings (see my earlier post about how this method is used to predict the salary of CEOs of big companies). It belongs to a class of sampling algorithms called Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC). This algorithm is known to be particularly efficient when the number of dimensions to be explored is very large. In practical terms, one has to create a derived class of BAT::BCModel and then define the set of parameters and their range (in this simple example they are all in the range [-100,100]). Most importantly, one has to implement the virtual function BCModel::LogLikelihood(std::vector<double>) to calculate the “evidence” term that appears in Bayes’ theorem as a function of the parameters H for each iteration of the MCMC. One can also re-implement the estimation of prior distributions, but to keep it simple they can be set to a gaussian distribution with mean 0 and standard deviation that covers 1/4 of the allowed range (100/4 = 25 in this example). That is a very crude assumption, which in principle could be replaced by an even less “informative” constant prior. However, the whole point of using Bayesian methods is to spell out our prior beliefs: in this case, I think it’s fair to say that one expects the value of the parameters to be small, but leave room for a better estimation. We’ll see later what this “update” actually looks like.

Inside the LogLikelihood() function, the parameters are passed to a FeedForward class that rearranges them and then actually performs the neural network calculation. The output is compared by the means of the cross-entropy loss with respect to the known label ([1,0,0] for setosa, [0,1,0] for versicolor and [0,0,1] for virginica). The MCMC engine draws random values of the parameters, calculates the loss, and proceeds to a nearby point according to Metropolis-Hastings algorithm. To further refine the optimization, the “exploration” is performed by a number of parallel chains (typically 4 or 8, up to one per CPU core) that ideally should converge to the same optimal point.

At the end of the process, the posterior distributions are available for single parameters (marginalized 1D distributions) or pairs of parameters (marginalized 2D distributions). Ideally, these 1D distributions should be gaussian around the most probable value of the corresponding network weight. As a matter of fact, neural networks are complicated systems that very rarely have a global maximum that can be efficiently identified. More likely, there will be a large set of local maxima that are good enough for the purpose of the classification problem at hand. This is reflected by a posterior distribution with multiple peaks, each corresponding to a different maximum. However, there isn’t a simple way to treat these cases, and some approximation is needed. In this implementation of the method, I decided to use the mean of the distribution as the weight, and the RMS as the uncertainty on the same weight. Also, from 2D marginalized distributions it is possible to estimate the covariance matrix, where the element C_ij is given for example by the Pearson correlation coefficient between the 2D-marginalized distributions of the i-th and j-th weights. This information is saved to a text file to be used for inference.

In the inference step, the weights of the network and the correlation matrix are loaded from the text file created at the end of the training. The neural network will be executed a number of times, and the results will be collected and averaged to get the final result.

Now it is time to clarify why we need to propagate the covariance matrix to the inference step: we can’t simply throw random numbers as if the weights were independent of each other, while they are in fact correlated. In principle, we would like to explore the complete N-dimensional probability distribution function for H*, but that’s too complicated. Rather, we can approximate it with a multivariate normal distribution X~N(μ,σ), that is the N-dimensional equivalent of the gaussian (μ is the vector of central values of the weights, and σ is the vector of standard deviations):

However, sampling from X is not a simple feat. It turns out that in 1D it is easier to turn a standard normal random variable Z~N(0,1) into a normal random variable N(μ,σ) by first scaling by the square root of the variance (i.e., the standard deviation) and then moving the result to have the correct mean (adding μ), i.e. X = μ + √σ * Z. The same idea holds in multiple dimensions, but instead of having a scalar value for the variance we have a covariance matrix. But wait: what is the square root of a matrix C? By definition it must look like C = C^(1/2)* (C^(1/2))^T. The most common method to find the matrix C^(1/2) is given by the Cholesky decomposition, where one gets a triangular matrix U such that C = U^T U (U turns out to be an upper triangular matrix, but an equivalent formulation with lower triangular matrix also exists). Hence, one simply gets X = μ + U^T*Z .
Finally, we classify a given event, and see what is the response of the neural network.
In the first case, the network has no problem to classify the flower: it is a …
In this other case, instead, the outcome is all but clear…

In particular, this last example seems to suggest that category #1 (versicolor) is more probable than category #2 (virginica). However, upon closer inspection, one can see that the two uncertainty bands overlap, reducing the statistical significance — in fact, this case is substantially unclassified, the only conclusion to be drawn being that this flower is unlikely to be an iris setosa.

To wrap up, this is a simple and nice example that shows how important it is not only to classify things, but also to attach an uncertainty to the decision. That’s how humans incorporate new information and apply their reason in a decision-making process. It’s probably not a big deal in the case under consideration, but as discussed in the book Weapons of Math Destruction by the American mathematician Cathy O’Neill, blindly trusting the outcome of AI/ML classifiers can have dire consequence in socioeconomic situations where people rather than flowers are the inputs.
NLP Machine Learning engineer at Ceridian. Formerly physicist at U Toronto, Bologna, CERN LHC/ATLAS.
